EastEnders writer defends racism storyline over ‚ÄòPoles go home‚Äô backlash 
Some viewers branded the scene "beyond disgusting" Wednesday 22 February 2017 08:35 GMT Click to follow Tube strike under way as transport bosses warn of rush-hour chaos 
EastEnders scriptwriter Leo Richardson has defended the recent racism storyline after he faced a backlash from viewers. 
The BBC soap tackled racism and xenophobia in a Brexit -fuelled plot which saw the words ‚ÄúPoles go home‚Äù graffitied on the Queen Vic after a Polish themed night at the pub. 
A group of locals were seen crowded round the venue in Tuesday night‚Äôs episode as Danny Dyer ‚Äôs character Mick Carter attempted to jet spray the offensive message off of the door. 
Denise Fox (Diane Parish) asked ‚Äúwhat on earth is going on in this place?‚Äù before Konrad Topolski (Piotr Baumann) said: ‚ÄúIt is the Britain we live in now.‚Äù 
One viewer described the scene as ‚Äúbeyond disgusting‚Äù while others accused the BBC of having an anti-Brexit agenda with one writing: ‚ÄúIncredible #Brexit bashing storyline on #EastEnders this evening. Normally this is The One Show territory. Prime time unabashed BBC bias.‚Äù 
Richardson tweeted in defence of the storyline after one viewer asked him to ‚Äúnot write for this soap again‚Äù. Read more Danny Dyer‚Äôs daughter Dani defends EastEnders star over ‚Äòstupid lies‚Äô 
Richardson hit back: ‚ÄúSo are you saying that racism doesn't exist? And that this isn't a very real problem in Britain today? 
‚ÄúWhat you saw on screen was a fictional character expressing his own belief. The side of a under represented group of people, I might add.

Others praised Richardson and said it was "brave and relevant to highlight the issue". 
Another wrote: "#Eastenders raising important topical issues tonight, good to see."
